webTitle: Daniel Johns sues News Corp for defamation over front-page brothel story

fields.headline: Daniel Johns sues News Corp for defamation over front-page brothel story
fields.standfirst: Former Silverchair frontman says article, which has since been removed from website, was ‘simply untrue’
fields.trailText: Former Silverchair frontman says article, which has since been removed from website, was ‘simply untrue’
fields.body:
Former Silverchair frontman Daniel Johns is suing the Sunday Telegraph in the supreme court of Victoria for publishing a front-page story which alleged that the notorious Sydney brothel The Kastle had become his second home.

Under the headline “King of the Kastle” last month reporter Amy Harris, who has been named along with editor Mick Carroll in the suit, said Johns had spent up to 18 hours a day at the brothel the previous two weeks.

But Johns says he has never been to the club and was not contacted before the story was published on 11 August.

“The article was simply untrue,” Johns said in a statement on Facebook on Thursday.

“No contact was made with me or my representatives to check the facts before the article was published.

“I have asked the newspaper for an apology and retraction. Neither has been provided.

“I have now issued legal proceedings in order to publicly correct the facts and vindicate my reputation.

“This false reporting has been very hurtful, humiliating, and damaging to me and my family. It is disappointing that the newspaper has not acknowledged this and apologised despite assertions from both myself, and a representative of the Kastle, that I simply was not, and have never been, there. In fact, I never even knew of its existence.”

News Corp did scrub all mention of the story from its website last month but declined to comment when approached by Guardian Australia.

The club’s owner immediately denied the story on social media and said Johns had never been a client.

Citing unnamed sources, the Telegraph story made a number of claims about Johns’ behaviour at the club, alongside details of the club’s services including claims that it specialises in “brown showers” and “adult babies”.

Links to the online version lead to a 404 error with a generic message stating the article “is no longer available”. The story has been entirely scrubbed from the digital edition of the newspaper.

The Kastle’s owner, who goes by the name Mistress Scarlett, denied the story, stating on social media that Johns had never been to the club.

“In response to today’s Daily Telegraph article, we state that Daniel Johns was not on the premises nor has been previously,” she wrote.

“We’re unsure of the source of this false information. In our 30-year history, we’ve never revealed the identity of clients and take privacy very seriously.”

Johns, 40, shot to fame as a teenager in the 1990s as the lead singer of grunge band Silverchair. From Newcastle in New South Wales, Johns was 15 when the band’s first album, Frogstomp, sold 3m copies worldwide. A multi-Aria-award-winning artist, he has also been part of a number of high-profile side projects including the Dissociatives with the dance music producer Paul Mac.

It would mark another in a string of defamation cases for the Telegraph’s owner Nationwide News. In May News was ordered to pay the Oscar-winning actor Geoffrey Rush $2.9m in damages after a series of articles accusing the Oscar-winning actor of “inappropriate behaviour” towards a female actor.

The former Channel 7 sports reporter Josh Massoud is also suing News – along with a number of other outlets including Nine and Fox Sports Australia – over their coverage of his departure from the network.
